title: 11th Street Bridge
listingDescription: Anacostia Park was a segregated park, with what is now the 11th St. Bridge serving as the segregation line.

images.altText: The underside of three bridges is depicted. Long, thick pillars hold each bridge up.
images.title: 11th Street Bridge
images.caption: 11th Street Bridge

bodyText:
Historic; segregation line 

 

Anacostia Park was a segregated park, with what is now the 11th St. Bridge serving as the segregation line. North of the bridge was the White section, with a golf course, pool, and many fields and courts. South of the Bridge was the Black section, a much smaller area with only courts and fields. Anacostia Park during this time was a clear representation of the failure of “separate but equal”. Segregation in Anacostia Park ended in 1949. 

 

The 11th Street Bridge first opened in 1965. Its construction coincided with the Interstate Highway System introduced by President Eisenhower. DC followed the trend of improved urban planning and infrastructure happening nationwide. In 2009, the bridge underwent a major renovation almost 50 years since its initial construction. The DC Department of Transportation (DDOT) replaced the bridge. At the time, it was the most expensive project they ever completed with an estimated cost of over $450 million dollars. This bridge is one of several bridges that connect DC on the east and west sides of the Anacostia River. From the bridge, it overlooks Anacostia Park to the north and south. It is where the political boundary lines for DC wards 6 and 8 meet. The bridge is 931 feet in length. On the eastern side of the bridge, 11th street ends and becomes Martin Luther King Avenue.
audioDescription: The underside of three bridges is depicted. Long, thick pillars hold each bridge up.

title: Anacostia Park Pirate Ship Playground
listingDescription: One of the most popular picnic areas in Anacostia Park the Fairlawn Picnic area, nicknamed "Pirate Ship Playground," offers restrooms, picnic tables and exercise equipment for adults and children. The fanciful pirate ship jungle gym reminds us of the ships that once sailed Anacostia's waters.

images.altText: Playground that looks like a pirate ship
images.title: Pirate Ship Playground
images.caption: Pirate Ship Playground

bodyText: One of the most popular picnic areas in Anacostia Park the Fairlawn Picnic area, nicknamed "Pirate Ship Playground," offers restrooms, picnic tables and exercise equipment for adults and children. The fanciful pirate ship jungle gym reminds us of the ships that once sailed Anacostia's waters.

title: Anacostia Recreation Center
listingDescription: Built during by the Works Projects Administration during the Great Depression, the Anacostia Recreation Center offers bike rentals, and picnic areas. A pool and weight room are free to Washington, DC, residents and available to others at a nominal fee. In 1949, the Recreation Center was the site of a major integration riot that ultimately paved the way for desegregation of public pools in the District of Columbia.

images.altText: Anacostia Recreation Center
images.title: Anacostia Recreation Center
images.caption: Anacostia Recreation Center

bodyText: Built during by the Works Projects Administration during the Great Depression, the Anacostia Recreation Center offers bike rentals, and picnic areas. A pool and weight room are free to Washington, DC, residents and available to others at a nominal fee. In 1949, the Recreation Center was the site of a major integration riot that ultimately paved the way for desegregation of public pools in the District of Columbia.
audioDescription: The Anacostia Recreation Center with a pool and weights room.

title: Anacostia Riverwalk Trail
listingDescription: The trail takes you through 12 miles of forest, fields, marsh and river ecosystem.

images.altText: A man smiles as he rides his bicycle down a paved trail.
images.title: Anacostia Riverwalk Trail
images.caption: The Anacostia Riverwalk Trail

bodyText:
The Anacostia Riverwalk Trail is a paved multi-use trail that runs along the Anacostia River. It is free and is open year-round during daylight hours. The trail is excellent for biking, jogging and walking. Pets are welcome along the trail as long as they are on a 6 foot or shorter leash. The trail is 3.5 miles long in Anacostia Park, but you have many options to extend your journey. You can do a 7.8 mile loop by crossing the Anacostia River and riding along the west bank or the river. You can also continue along the trail north to Bladensburg Park in Maryland, or south by going across one of the bridges into downtown DC to the Capitol Hill and Navy Yard neighborhoods.   

Local attractions along the trail in Anacostia Park include the Anacostia Park Pavillion, where you can rent roller-skates from Memorial Day until Labor Day. The Anacostia Pool, tennis courts, basketball courts and many athletic fields provide the opportunity for sports and recreation. The trail connects other nearby areas to explore including the Kenilworth Aquatic Gardens, River Terrace Park, the Maine Avenue Fish Market and Wharf, Nationals Park, Historic Anacostia, and the Bladensburg Marina Park.  

The newest portion of the riverwalk trail that extended Benning Road NE to the Bladensburg Trail was completed in 2016. Mileage markers were completed in 2022 to assist in navigation and directions for trail users.
audioDescription: The Anacostia Riverwalk Trail is a paved trail with a yellow stripe down the middle. Trail users should keep to the right side of the walkway, and pass carefully on the left. The trail is approximately 8 feet wide.

title: Anacostia Roller Skating Pavilion
listingDescription: Can you remember the last time you laced up a pair of roller skates? Make new memories with this â€˜fun for the whole family' activity. Skate rentals are free and available during summer months. On summer weekends DJ music adds to the fun. This is the one and only roller skating rink owned and operated by the National Park Service!

images.altText: A visitor dressed in 1970s attire skates in the pavilion.
images.title: Anacostia Roller Skating Pavilion
images.caption: Several visitors celebrated 100 years of the National Park Service at the Anacostia Park Roller Skat

bodyText: Can you remember the last time you laced up a pair of roller skates? Make new memories with this â€˜fun for the whole family' activity. Skate rentals are free and available during summer months. On summer weekends DJ music adds to the fun. This is the one and only roller skating rink owned and operated by the National Park Service!
audioDescription:
(296 words)
The Anacostia Roller Skating Pavilion is located in the southeast quadrant of Washington, D.C., north of Anacostia Park along the east bank of the Anacostia River.
From the Sousa Bridge underpass at Anacostia Drive, SE, travel seven hundred fifty feet north on Anacostia Drive. Turn right and continue along Anacostia Drive about four hundred yards. Turn left into the parking lot. The Anacostia Roller Skating Pavilion sits beyond the parking lot, about one hundred feet to the northwest.
The pavilion is an open-air, one-story, rectangular structure, about two hundred thirty feet long and one hundred forty feet wide.
Round cement columns, about twenty feet apart, line each side and support the pavilion's wood roof. In each corner are one-story brown stone buildings, each about forty square feet with rounded ends.
The southeast building has a curved front window where a National Park Service attendant is available to provide skating equipment and park information. The northeast structure houses restrooms. Two additional brown, curved structures sit at the northwest and southwest corners of the pavilion.
A wide-open smooth cement roller skating surface sits underneath the pavilion roof. The open sides provide an abundance of natural light into the space, and two steps along the sides allow for seating. Metal girders above sit on the underside of the wooden beams of the roof. Brown panels line the north and south sides of the roof. On the east and west side, the roof line is open and the roof's metal girders are visible.
The parking lot spans over five hundred feet and a basketball court sits to the west of the pavilion. Grass fields and open space line both north and south sides along the Anacostia River and the Kenilworth Avenue Freeway runs beyond the parking lot to the west.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Anacostia boat ramp
listingDescription: Anacostia Park doesn't just have great view of the river, it has public access! The boat ramp is located at the north end of Anacostia Drive SE. Vehicle and trailer parking is adjacent to the boat ramp. Review D.C.'s Harbor and Boating Safety Regulations prior to launching your watercraft.

images.altText: A boat ramp leads into the Anacostia river
images.title: Anacostia boat ramp
images.caption: Anacostia boat ramp

bodyText: Anacostia Park doesn't just have great view of the river, it has public access! The boat ramp is located at the north end of Anacostia Drive SE. Vehicle and trailer parking is adjacent to the boat ramp. Review D.C.'s Harbor and Boating Safety Regulations prior to launching your watercraft.

title: Aquatic Resources Center
listingDescription: Aquatic Resources Education Center is the host to 20-1,500-gallon aquariums where visitors can have insight of what's beneath the waves of the Anacostia and to learn about the variety of aquatic life that is supported by the river. Well over 40 species of fish, amphibians, reptiles, and invertebrates from the District and the Chesapeake Bay are on display at the facility. The AREC is a multi-use environmental education center located in Anacostia Park, SE run by DOEE.

images.altText: A building with brick exterior has a ramp leading to the entrance. A sign is on the front.
images.title: Aquatic Resources Center
images.caption: Aquatic Resources Center

Well over 40 species of fish, amphibians, reptiles, and invertebrates from the District and the Chesapeake Bay are on display at the facility. The AREC is a multi-use environmental education center located in Anacostia Park, SE run by DOEE.

title: Basketball Courts
listingDescription: The Anacostia Park Basketball Court is a space for visitors to play pick-up or be able to open shoot. The basketball court is located next to the skating pavilion. The basketball courts are open all year round and from sunrise to sunset. There are 8 basketball hoops and two court spaces.

images.altText: Two basketball hops stand adjacent on a basketball court. A brown building is positioned behind them
images.title: Basketball Courts
images.caption: Basketball Courts

bodyText: The Anacostia Park Basketball Court is a space for visitors to play pick-up or be able to open shoot. The basketball court is located next to the skating pavilion. The basketball courts are open all year round and from sunrise to sunset. There are 8 basketball hoops and two court spaces.
audioDescription: Two basketball hops stand adjacent on a basketball court. A brown building is positioned behind them.

title: Frederick Douglass Memorial Bridge
listingDescription: The Frederick Douglass Memorial Bridge is located at the southern edge of Anacostia Park and carries South Capitol Street over the Anacostia River into Washington, D.C.

images.altText: A white bridge has three, half-circular designs on either side. Blue water is stagnant below.
images.title: Frederick Douglass Memorial Bridge
images.caption: Frederick Douglass Memorial Bridge

bodyText:
The Frederick Douglass Memorial Bridge is located at the southern edge of Anacostia Park and carries South Capitol Street over the Anacostia River into Washington, D.C. It is named for the famed social reformer, abolitionist, orator, writer, and statesman, Fredrick Douglass. Construction of the bridge started in 2018 and was completed in 2021. The bridge is 1,600-feet long and consists of three sets of parallel white arches. There are six lanes of traffic and a joint bicycle-pedestrian path on both sides. 

 

Frederick Douglass spent his life fighting for justice and equality. Born into slavery in 1818, he escaped as a young man and became a leading voice in the abolitionist movement. Douglass moved to Anacostia in 1878. Douglass used to spend much of his time walking down the Anacostia River. He was a talented botanist and would collect plants and study the environment.
audioDescription: A white bridge has three, half-circular designs on either side. Blue water is stagnant below.

title: Good Hope Road Park Entrance
listingDescription: Good Hope Road is one of three entrances into Anacostia Park.

images.altText: Four signs are displayed on three posts. The letters displayed are white on a gray/brown background.
images.title: Good Hope Road Park Entrance
images.caption: Good Hope Road Park Entrance

bodyText: Good Hope Road is one of three entrances into Anacostia Park. In order to enter the park, you will first pass through the DC-295 underpass. At the end of the road, you will see your first glimpse of the Anacostia River. You might also notice the Anacostia Riverwalk Trail (ART). The ART is a paved trail frequently used by cyclists, runners, and walkers and serves as the backbone of the Anacostia Waterfront. It stretches 12-miles along the river from South Capitol Street north to Kenilworth Aquatic Gardens. Turning right on Anacostia Drive will take you to the DC Recreation Center, Skating Pavilion, Aquatic Education Center, and boat ramp. Turning left will take you to the National Capitol Parks – East Headquarters and the South Capitol Street entrance/exit of the park.
audioDescription: Good Hope Road intersects with Anacostia Drive at this location, which is the main road that runs throughout the park.

title: Historic Site: Malcolm X Day
listingDescription: For over 23 years, May 19th was a tremendous day in Anacostia Park. To celebrate pioneering civil rights activist Malcom X’s birthday, tens of thousands of people would come to the park to hear activists, artists, community leaders and more. Beginning in 1972, the message of the yearly event was to celebrate and create unity in the surrounding community. The events featured community organizing, art, music, and a general celebration of culture.

images.altText: An open field has a building behind it. Trees and picnic tables are in the background.
images.title: Historic Site: Malcolm X Day
images.caption: Historic Site: Malcolm X Day

bodyText: For over 23 years, May 19th was a tremendous day in Anacostia Park. To celebrate pioneering civil rights activist Malcolm X’s birthday, tens of thousands of people would come to the park to hear activists, artists, community leaders and more. Beginning in 1972, the message of the yearly event was to celebrate and create unity in the surrounding community. The events featured community organizing, art, music, and a general celebration of culture.
audioDescription: An open field has a building behind it. Trees and picnic tables are in the background.

title: Historic site: 1949 Anacostia Pool Riot
listingDescription: The Anacostia Park swimming pool became the center of a riot in 1949 when the pool was set to be integrated.

images.altText: Two picnic tables sit in an open field. A white building with a brick roof is in the background.
images.title: Historic site: 1949 Anacostia Pool Riot
images.caption: Historic site: 1949 Anacostia Pool Riot

bodyText: The Anacostia Park swimming pool became the center of a riot in 1949 when the pool was set to be integrated. Before 1949 the pool was only open to White Americans, and Black Americans were not welcome. When Black residents tried to access the pool that summer, White residents harassed them. The fighting continued and the police did not help to enforce the integration but instead arrested some individuals supporting equal access to the pool. The pool was closed for the rest of the summer in response. The following summer the pool was open to all people, but most White residents did not return.
audioDescription: Two picnic tables sit in an open field. A white building with a brick roof is in the background.

title: Information Panel: Bonus Army
listingDescription: In May 1932, jobless veterans organized a group called the "Bonus Expeditionary Forces" that marched on Washington, DC, to demand an advance on a bonus payment they had been promised for their World War I service. Led by Walter W. Walters, the veterans set up camps and occupied buildings in various locations in Washington, DC. The largest camp was a shantytown here on the Anacostia Flats, across the river from Washington's Navy Yard. By summer, at least 20,000 people had join

images.altText: A group of men armed with bricks and pipes fights with a group of police armed with nightsticks. One
images.title: Bonus Army protesters clash with police,
images.caption: Bonus Army protesters clash with police, July 28, 1932

bodyText: In May 1932, jobless veterans organized a group called the "Bonus Expeditionary Forces" that marched on Washington, DC, to demand an advance on a bonus payment they had been promised for their World War I service. Led by Walter W. Walters, the veterans set up camps and occupied buildings in various locations in Washington, DC. The largest camp was a shantytown here on the Anacostia Flats, across the river from Washington's Navy Yard. By summer, at least 20,000 people had joined the camps. When a bill to give the veterans their payment early failed in Congress, many of the protesters moved on, but many also stayed, so President Hoover sent in the army - led by Gen. Douglas MacArthur - to push them out on July 28. The camp was still inhabited by about 10,000 people, who were driven off by the cavalry with tanks and tear gas while infantry set fire to the shanties. DC's hospitals were overwhelmed with the wounded. Deemed an operational success for the army, the political fallout was a disaster for President Hoover, who lost his re-election bid later that year.
audioDescription:
(184 words)
The Bonus Army wayside and marker is located along the southern bank of the Anacostia River in Anacostia Park in Washington, D.C. An updated wayside is planned for this location.
From the intersection of Anacostia Drive and Good Hope Road, SE, travel eight hundred feet south on Anacostia Drive. Set on the right side of the bicycle path along the north side of the road is a one by two-foot light gray sign that reads in white letters:
Bonus Army
Wayside
At Good Hope Road
Two feet south of the sign is a curved white stone semi-circle wall, about two feet tall, arced around the north side of a fifteen-foot wide circular cement plaza. The plaza features a pink and gray checkered border and star pattern in the middle. Set in the center is a bronze compass with a similar star design.
A black arched bicycle rack sits between the plaza and wayside. Trees and overgrown vegetation line the river's edge, obscuring the view. Across 17th street is a large grass field to the north and a U.S. Park Police Facility to the south.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Langston Golf Course
listingDescription: Under the shadow of segregation, the Langston Golf Course was built to service the nearby African American community in 1939. It was one of twenty golf courses in America that was open to African Americans; whites had 680 to choose from. Washington, DC, was the birthplace of the first men's and women's African American golf clubs: the Riverside Golf Club (1924), now the Royal Golf Club, and the Wake Robin Golf Club, originally comprised of the wives of Riverside members who w

images.altText: A golf course with sand pits and trees
images.title: Langston Golf Course
images.caption: Langston Golf Course

bodyText:
Under the shadow of segregation, the Langston Golf Course was built to service the nearby African American community in 1939. It was one of twenty golf courses in America that was open to African Americans; whites had 680 to choose from. Washington, DC, was the birthplace of the first men's and women's African American golf clubs: the Riverside Golf Club (1924), now the Royal Golf Club, and the Wake Robin Golf Club, originally comprised of the wives of Riverside members who were tired of being left at home alone all weekend.
Inscriptions
LANGSTON GOLF COURSE
HAS BEEN PLACED ON THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES
BY THE UNITED STATES
DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR
1991
A HISTORIC SITE OPENED
JUNE 9TH, 1939
NAMED FOR
JOHN MERCER LANGSTON
audioDescription:
(300 words)
Langston Golf Course is an 18-hole golf course located in the northeast quadrant of Washington, DC, north of Benning Road.
The course's front nine holes are located just south of the National Arboretum. Part of the course's back nine holes are located on Kingman Island, which is bordered by the Anacostia River to the east and Kingman Lake to the west.
From the intersection of Benning Road, NE and 26th street, NE travel north on 26th street two hundred sixty feet. Turn right, travel about fifty feet and enter the parking lot.
A four hundred-fifty-foot long, one hundred fifty-foot wide parking lot sits to the left. To the right a cement walkway runs by a one-story red brick building, one hundred thirty feet long and ninety feet wide. Inside the building is the golf course pro shop and a small kitchen and refreshment area.
A porch is on the east facing side of the building, set with tables and chairs and looks out at the golf course. The south end of the golf course lines Benning Road. A row of golf carts sits along the east side of the building.
Two bronze plaques are set on the south wall of the porch area, each about one-square foot. Above them is a brown arrowhead-shaped National Park Service sign. Text on the top plaque reads:
LANGSTON GOLF COURSE
HAS BEEN PLACED ON THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES
BY THE UNITED STATES
DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR
1991
Text on the lower plaque reads:
A HISTORIC SITE OPENED
JUNE 9TH, 1939
NAMED FOR
JOHN MERCER LANGSTON
A white metal fence lines the east edge of the walkway beside the brick building. Further east the golf course runs from Benning Road north towards the National Arboretum. Trees and sand traps line the course throughout.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Nicholson Street SE Entrance
listingDescription: Follow I-395 North to I-295 South. Follow signs for Martin Luther King Blvd. After approaching the bridge, you should see signs for Anacostia Park.

images.altText: A highway bridge is positioned behind four signs directing location.
images.title: Nicholson Street SE Entrance
images.caption: Nicholson Street SE Entrance

bodyText:
Follow I-395 North to I-295 South. Follow signs for Martin Luther King Blvd. 
 
After approaching the bridge, you should see signs for Anacostia Park. Get in the left center lane. The park exit is at the end of the bridge and is somewhat obscured. It is a sharp turn so be ready for it. 
 
Go down the ramp and make a right. The Park entrance is straight ahead. 
 
Turn right. The fields are on the right. Park in the big parking lot to the left of the recreation center. 

From points NORTH (Anacostia Blvd N or S) 
 
Take the Pennsylvania Ave East Exit. 
 
Turn right on to Minnesota Av. 
 
Turn right on Nicholson St. This will take you straight to the park entrance.
audioDescription: A highway bridge is positioned behind four signs directing location.

title: River Terrace Park
listingDescription: River Terrace Park is a lovely community park located in the River Terrace neighborhood of NE Washington DC. The park sits along the east bank of the Anacostia River, providing great views of the flowing tidal river. Wildlife is abundant on the river including ducks, geese, beavers and river otters. Park amenities include a children's playground, a covered pavilion, two basketball courts (full court), two tennis courts and a paved walking trail.

images.altText: A sign reading, "River Terrace Park" is positioned in a grassy field with trees.
images.title: River Terrace Park
images.caption: River Terrace Park

bodyText:
River Terrace Park is a lovely community park located in the River Terrace neighborhood of NE Washington DC. The park sits along the east bank of the Anacostia River, providing great views of the flowing tidal river. Wildlife is abundant on the river including ducks, geese, beavers and river otters. Park amenities include a children's playground, a covered pavilion, two basketball courts (full court), two tennis courts and a paved walking trail. The trail is part of the Anacostia Riverwalk Trail that continues south to Anacostia Park and north to Kenilworth Aquatic Gardens.  
 

Adjacent to the park is the River Terrace neighborhood. Bordered by Interstate 295, Benning Road and Pennsylvania Avenue, the neighborhood is known as a "modest jewel" tucked away in NE Washington. The neighborhood has a lot of nice front porches and pretty gardens that beautify the area. Nearby amenities just across the Anacostia River include the Langston Golf Course and Kingman and Heritage Island Parks.
audioDescription: A sign reading, "River Terrace Park" is positioned in a grassy field with trees.

title: Seafarer’s Yacht Club
listingDescription: In 1945, Lewis T. Green made history in Anacostia Park when he created the Seafarers Yacht Club. The Seafarers is the oldest African American yacht club in the country.

images.altText: Multiple, white yachts are parked at a dock. Blue, calm water is in the foreground.
images.title: Seafarer’s Yacht Club
images.caption: Seafarer’s Yacht Club

bodyText: In 1945, Lewis T. Green made history in Anacostia Park when he created the Seafarers Yacht Club. The Seafarers is the oldest African American yacht club in the country. It was founded by Green, an art teacher in DC Public Schools, who enjoyed building boats in his free time. At first his application for the land was ignored, but after help from civil rights leader Mary McLeod Bethune, he was able to establish the club and rent the space. The Yacht Club is still thriving to this day and was an early advocate for stewarding the river.
audioDescription: Multiple, white yachts are parked at a dock. Blue, calm water is in the foreground.

title: Sousa Bridge
listingDescription: Named after John Philip Sousa this bridge carries Pennsylvania Avenue, America's main street, across the Anacostia River and into the heart of Washington. Born a half-mile from the bridge, John Philip Sousa built the Marine Band into one of the most famous musical groups in the world. Known as "the March King," Sousa composed many marches, the most famous being "The Stars and Stripes Forever." Sousa is buried in Congressional Cemetery, just on the other side of the bridge.

images.altText: Sousa Bridge
images.title: Sousa Bridge
images.caption: Sousa Bridge

bodyText: Named after John Philip Sousa this bridge carries Pennsylvania Avenue, America's main street, across the Anacostia River and into the heart of Washington. Born a half-mile from the bridge, John Philip Sousa built the Marine Band into one of the most famous musical groups in the world. Known as "the March King," Sousa composed many marches, the most famous being "The Stars and Stripes Forever." Sousa is buried in Congressional Cemetery, just on the other side of the bridge.
audioDescription:
(181 words)
The Sousa Bridge is a continuous steel plate girder bridge that carries Pennsylvania Avenue SE across the Anacostia River in Washington, D.C. The Congressional Cemetery sits to the northeast at the north end of the bridge.
From the intersection of Water street SE and M street SE, travel west five hundred yards on M street, under the overpass of the Sousa Bridge. Set on a one hundred-foot strip of grass, between M street and the Anacostia Riverwalk Trail, is a two square foot light gray sign. Written on both sides in white letters it reads:
Sousa Bridge Wayside.
The arches of the bridge carry over M street and two lines of railroad tracks to the north. Access to this location from the north is not possible due to closed roads. The location can be reached along the Anacostia Riverwalk Trail, and pedestrian trail that runs east to west along the edge of the Anacostia River.
The south end of the bridge crosses Anacostia Drive and Anacostia Fields, open grass field areas that run three quarters of a mile to the southwest.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: South Capitol Street Park Entrance
listingDescription: Follow the Suitland parkway toward Washington, DC. Turn right at the fourth traffic signal to turn onto firth sterling avenue. Take the next left turn on Howard Street. When you arrive to the Douglas bridge, the lanes split into 4 exits. Take the fourth exit and the park entrance is on the right.

images.altText: Two crosswalks are connected by a sidewalk. A tall, black lamp post is positioned next to signage.
images.title: South Capitol Street Park Entrance
images.caption: South Capitol Street Park Entrance

bodyText:
Follow the Suitland parkway toward Washington, DC 

Turn right at the fourth traffic signal to turn onto firth sterling avenue. Take the next left turn on Howard Street.  

When you arrive to the Douglas bridge, the lanes split into 4 exits.  

Take the fourth exit and the park entrance is on the right.
audioDescription: Two crosswalks are connected by a sidewalk. A tall, black lamp post is positioned next to signage.

title: Tennis Courts and Playground
listingDescription: There are multiple tennis courts and a playground at Anacostia Park next to the Recreation Center. The tennis courts and playground are open to use by the public anytime.

images.altText: A playground area has three yellow slides and brown/orange railings. Tennis courts are in the back.
images.title: Tennis Courts and Playground
images.caption: Tennis Courts and Playground

bodyText: There are multiple tennis courts and a playground at Anacostia Park next to the Recreation Center. The tennis courts and playground are open to use by the public anytime.
audioDescription: A playground area has three yellow slides and brown/orange railings. Tennis courts are in the background.
